Name: Whamgammon
Description:
The game is played very much like regular backgammon... to a point. The first player to get all of his pieces off his home board is the winner.  Unlike normal backgammon, however, there are no safe spaces.  When your piece(es) land(s) in the same space as an opponent's piece(es), they do battle (rolling dice and comparing the result against a defense factor) until one side controls the space and the other (or both) has been sent back to the bar. In addition, one of the pieces has a special power (the Summoner) that really changes the flow of Backgammon.

The advanced game includes fortifications which further complicate things.

The version available in the Winter 2006 edition of the Crusader must be glued down and then cut out before play. The self published edition comes glued to crescent board and you must cut it out before play.

Name: Trivial Pursuit: ToGO! Pop Culture 2
Description:
This POP CULTURE edition features 600 questions (on 100 cards) from popular TV shows, commercials and movies, as well as questions about your favorite songs, hot gossip and popular fads.

A portable wedge shaped carrying case contains 100 cards, two rule cards and a "wedge die".  Roll the wedge-die to determine the category of question to ask.  If the question is answered correctly, roll the die a second time to select a 2nd question.  If the 2nd question is answered correctly, keep the card as a score "wedge".  Be the first to collect six cards and win the game.

Name: Interstellar Warfare
Description:
Sir... Shields down, taking internal damage, we must withdraw.  
That's enough Ensign! Hold Position! We must hold the line until the cruisers arrive...
Engineering get those shields up now!, or we wont see tomorrow.

Interstellar Warfare brings the simplicity and flexibility of cards to the realm of tactical space combat games allowing players to easily design ships, manage power, record damage and more without ever putting pen to paper or using complicated math. Players simply select ship hull panels and add ship system cards to design new warships. Construct warships to fill various roles within your fleet and send them into battle to devastate your enemies.
Families: Players: Wargames with Rules Supporting Only Two Players

Name: Christian Fluxx
Description:
These are 7 cards to add to a regular Fluxx deck. The cards in this set include Christian themes of The Cross and the Story of Jesus and give a player a bonus for knowing or showing their Christian faith.

Fluxx is a card game where the cards themselves determine the current rules of the game. By playing cards, you change numerous aspects of the game: how to draw cards, how to play cards, and even how to win.

At the start of the game, each player holds three cards and on a turn a player draws one card, then plays one card. By playing cards, you can put new rules into play that change numerous aspects of the game: how many cards to draw or play, how many cards you can hold in hand or keep on the table in front of you, and (most importantly) how to win the game.

Part of the Fluxx series.

Name: Jewish Fluxx
Description:
These are 7 cards to add to a regular Fluxx deck. The cards in this set include Jewish themes of The Torah and Shabbat and give the player a bonus for showing or knowing their Jewish heritage.

Expands:

    Fluxx


Part of the Fluxx series.

Name: Trendsetters
Description:
Can You Predict the Trends of Your Friends?

Here’s a party game that tests your ability to stay with The Mainstream. Players use their voting wheels to register secret votes on poll questions. The object is to select the most popular choice and stay in The Mainstream. After revealing their answers, players who are not in The Mainstream get a strike. First player to register 5 strikes on his or her scoring wheel pays a penalty for being Passé. The group chooses a penalty before play begins, such as clucking like a chicken or singing “I Write the Songs” by Barry Manilow.)

Name: DidYa Know
Description: A wonderfully simple game that can be enjoyed by young and old alike. Whether spending time together at home or traveling on vacation, families and friends can have a few laughs together sharing their own life stories by answering the DidYa Know story questions. Things really get interesting when players swap cards and then attempt to re-tell each other’s stories.

Name: Kotsuku
Description:
A Sudoku Grid for Word Gamers

Kotsuku is a grid-based game with an added competitive dimension as players vie to be the first to complete a word in the grid. Players take turns placing letters in the grid one letter at a time. Each letter in the alphabet may be used once per game. The object is to be the first person to complete a word of three or more letters. Words may be vertical, horizontal, diagonal either frontward or backwards. Use your letters wisely and be sure not to leave an opening for your opponent!

Name: Zero In
Description: Listen to clues and try to Zero In on the names of the celebrities that they describe. Players take turns posing as celebrities, giving other players clues so that they can guess the celeb’s identity. Watch out! The clues can be tricky and you only get one guess for each celebrity. A player reads clues for other players until someone guesses the celebrity’s name or clues are exhausted. If you’re the first one to Zero In on the celebrity’s name, you win the points for the last clue read. The first player to reach 12 points wins.

Name: Letter Hold 'em
Description:
A Word Game for Poker Players

This is a challenging contest that will have you reaching for your chips AND your dictionary! This game follows the same basic structure as Texas Hold ‘em (combine the cards in your hand with the face-up cards in the “flop” to make the strongest poker hand), only the playing cards also have letters on them. You must use your cards to spell a word, and then make the best possible poker hand using only the cards in the word.

Name: Roll'em Show'em
Description:
ROLL’EM SHOW’EM is a fun and exciting game of Strategy, Challenge, Skill, Will, Luck and Love. Wherein, the players advance in the game by complying to a variety of twists and tasks. They range anywhere from kissing an opposing player, having to remove an article of clothing or having to place a dividend of money into the pot for the winner in the end and much more.

The Tasks are given in means by either from the results of the thrown colored Blue and White Dies, The Big Black Task Die, the ROLL’EM SHOW’EM Task Deck of Cards, or by a command from an opposing participating player. By the way the winner of the game is the person who just happens to be the last player standing with either clothing left on, or money left in hand.

ROLL’EM SHOW’EM is a game that will keep you on the edge of your seat. Oh and by the way, keep your eyes wide open as well, you aren’t going to want to miss anything.

ROLL’EM SHOW’EM is designed and created with adult content, and it is intended to be played by Adults, with 2-12 players. So, in a game it could  be just you and that special someone, or you can have a group of friends at a party, either way you are sure to have a BLAST!!  OH YEAH.

Name: Blitz
Description:
The players have 8 different army units. Each one has a different strength, from 1 to 8. With those, players must try to conquer the opponent's capital, on the other side of the board. The first one to do so wins.

This is a direct reskin of Jungle with a military theme.

Name: Alpha Strike
Description:
Incoming Fire...  Evasive Action!

Divert Power to shields and Launch Fighters!

Alpha Strike is a fast paced card game of tactical combat in deep space. Players take on the role of starship captains, managing power levels to keep their ship combat ready while utilizing their ships capabilities to defend themselves and unleash devastating attacks upon their opponents.

Alpha Strike comes complete with everything needed to play including starship control panels, a Combat Deck, Markers, and rules for two player duels and multi-player battles.

Name: Ultima Generation: Road to the Avatar TCG
Description:
Collectible Card Game based on the "Ultima Online" game world, which licensed by Electronic Arts.

In the game of Ultima Generation, players become one of the lords in Britannia. The main casting factors in the game are eight virtues as in Ultima - Spirituality, Honor, Compassion, Valor, Justice, Honesty, Sacrifice, and Humility. Good lord summons adventures with positive virtues and summoning monsters costs virtues or minus virtue status for evil lord. Lord who defends her territory and controls the eight virtues wins the competition.

Name: SexPlay the Game
Description:
From the back of the box:

When Foreplay Just Isn't Enough

If you love sex... If you want variety and newness... If you are seeking new "Xperiences" together...
SEXPLAY is created just for you and your lover.

SEXPLAY offers delicious pleasuring and erotic enjoyment with endless sexual possibilities.

SEXPLAY encourages you and your lover to be playful and to enjoy all the secret delights of each other without pressure of performance.

SEXPLAY enhances your lovemaking and breathes a new level of "Xcitement" into your love life.

SEXPLAY is a fun game that's easy to play and you both win all the time.  It also makes a great gift!

SEXPLAY is for any consenting couple 18 to 80, single, married or living together, who want more stimulation, escapades, and arousing sexual "Xperiences."

The SEXPLAY gameboard consists of 6 spinners that offer innumerable provocative sexual scenarios that are action packed, playful and unpredictable!  Complete instructions are included.

No matter what sexual relationship you are in, YOU DESERVE SEXPLAY ...NOW!

Name: Simino
Description:
Simino is a color matching game. 
Simino game box includes 49 Simino cards, four card holders, score sheets and Simino game board. Simino can be played by one to four people. The main goal of this game is obtaining the highest score by matching the colors of the sides of Simino cards that are placed in a location on the Simino board. Meanwhile, a player should consider minimizing the total score that an opponent attempts to obtain. Simino is the name of the best move in the game. A Simino move is played if a player places all of his/her four cards all at once on the Simino board during his/her turn in the game. Actually, a player can only place one card at a time during his/her turn. But if s/he can make a Simino move, then it is possible for him/her to place all of the cards s/he has at once.
There are two groups of cards in Simino: Regular and Joker. A regular card can have a single color at each side, where as a Joker card can contain one side having two to four colors and the rest having a single color. Each side has a score associated with them.

Name: Flip Flop Faces
Description:
From DrToy.com

"This is a combination bean bag toss and silly faces that become targets that flip when you hit them the right way. The child will build their eye/hand coordination, depth perception, and accuracy as they toss plus they will learn math skills as they keep score. There are six target cups and six bean bags. The product also promotes gross motor skills and visual thinking. When the child is playing with this kind of game they are learning how to master playground games, sports and learning to take turns. It encourage the child to position their body and focus on throwing and social skills."

Name: minizoomerz Basic Game
Description:
minizoomerz - miniature racing on a grand scale

Game website : http://www.minizoomerz.com/

The minizoomerz Basic Game is a miniature motor racing game for 2-4 players aged 10years and up.

It is freely available as a print and play .pdf file from The Big Play's online store - http://www.thebigplay.co.uk/store

The 14 page .pdf file includes all the rules, tokens and counters you need to get started racing. A 'figure 8' circuit is included and introduces players to the Wild Canyons terrain. All you need to add are three six-sided dice.

Players can choose to move at fast speed to allow them to make maneuvers or go flat out at Furious speed. This decision dictates the number of dice they roll and the options they have during their move.

Players can pick up Fatigue during the race which can have an adverse effect on their performance at the later stages of the race. However, this can be managed and creates an ongoing 'risk assessment' aspect to the game in addition to choosing when to switch lanes and other situational decisions.

There is an accessory pack available for the game which includes 4 plastic miniature racing cars, 3 dice and 4 Special Ability cards which add an extra dimension to the games.

The Basic Game is also supported by expansion 'Toolkits', the first of which is the Wild Canyons which adds extra 'track sections' allowing players to design and create their own tracks and circuits.

Expanded by:

    minizoomerz: Wild Canyons Toolkit

Name: Strike It Lucky
Description:
Strike it Lucky

FROM THE BOX: Strike it Lucky is the authentic game of ITV's successful quiz show, hosted by Michael Barrymore. In the game, players accumulate money by moving around the board and correctly answering questions. When a player has won E4,000 all the players race across the TV screens trying to get to the other side without hitting too many Hot Spots. The player with the most money is the winner.

Strike it Rich

FROM THE BOX: Strike it Rich blends excitement with risk as you race your way across the board answering questions and avoiding the Hot Spots.

(NOTE: The game includes the original 'Hot Spot' sound module.)

Based on the hit ITV quiz show from the UK of the same name from 1986 to 1996 (and much later as Michael Barrymore's Strike it Rich from 1996 to 1999) hosted by Michael Barrymore, which in turn is based on the short-lived, 1986-87 American game show called Strike it Rich hosted by the late Joe Garagiola.

Name: Hühnerjagd
Description: In this game your current home is a chicken coop. You are a chicken and want your freedom. Your fellow players - who are also chickens - are also looking to escape. Your only money is chicken fodder you have saved. And the farmer knows your plans to escape and will try to defeat them! Will you be able to get out?

Name: The Whites of their Eyes:  A Guide to the American Revolution
Description:
"The Whites of their Eyes" is an introductory miniatures guidebook for the American Revolution using the system published in "Habitants and Highlanders" and "Rockets Red Glare".  The author includes an overview of the war, strategy and tactics, and a uniform guide.  Most of the book is a series of scenarios from the American Revolution (both skirmishes and battle), including maps and orders of battle for both sides.

Unlike other books in the Canadian Wargames Group series, the miniatures rules themselves are not included (you must have "Habitants" or "Rockets"), but a boardgame on the siege of Quebec and a campaign game "Washington and Howe" is provided.  Also included are systems for using the Avalon Hill games "1776: The Game of the American Revolutionary War" and "We the People" as campaign systems.
Families: Series: Canadian Wargamers Group Miniatures Rules

Name: The Siege of Draman Del
Description:
Draman Del is an ancient fortress city in a mountain pass, the only pass between the west and east lands.

The west is represented by a confederation of kingdoms (Nath, Drakand, Draman, Randrom, Svariji, Land people) formerly known as "Draman". Draman Del is the only fortification against the east people, the barbarians called Zenith; if it should fall, the barbarians may swarm over the west kingdoms.

The Seven Black Generals all host a shard of the soul of the evil god Zadrak and have been asleep for thousands of years but now, unknown to all, they are awakening. One of them, Xishayah, under the name of Kan Zenith, has gathered the nomadic Zenith tribes and is leading them to attack the west. To do this the legendary fortress of Draman Del must fall before General Adran arrives with reinforcements.

The beautiful map shows a top-down view of the Draman Del fortress. The entire city was built using a 3D modeling program and rendered it with textures and shades. On one side are placed some useful charts.The map is 22x17 inches.

Inside The Siege Of Draman Del you will find:

-A set of rules,

-Four mapsheet (game board)

-One countersheet with a total of 287 counters

-Tables and charts

-PDF Version only

Name: Witch Mountain
Description: Players put seven cubes in the shaker cup and then roll the cubes on the table.  The Witches, Dragons or Colors facing up are the Witches, Dragons or Colors used to advance the pawns.  The Starting color for each player is the color of their pawns and their color forms a trail in a spiral towards the middle of the board, then turns into Witch Mountain.  The first player to advance their three pawns to Witch Mountain is the winner.

Name: Blow! Bugles! Blow!
Description:
Blow! Bugles! Blow! is a set of six scenarios for Jolly Roger's A Nation on Trial rules:  First Manassas, Shiloh, Second Manassas, Antietam, Fredericksburg, and Chancellorsville.  Each scenario includes a battle map, order of battle, and scenario special rules.

One interesting feature of the scenario maps is that there are no units shown.  Players could, for example, scan the maps, print them out, and play on them.  The scale is 9" = 1 mile (approx. 1"=200 yds.).

Expands:

    A Nation on Trial

Name: Fairyland Princess
Description:
From the "Shirley Barber's Fairies" world so popular among Australian five year old girls. Players move around a board by rolling dice and then by landing on the correct spaces need to , in order: bring their six butterflies into their garden, move their fairy into the garden and then collect the stars from the Queen Fairy. The player with the most stars wins the game.

The game recommends for ages 4+ although there is some text on the board.

From the game box:

The world of Fairyland comes to life in this fun butterfly game for 2-6 players. Catch all your butterflies and then aim for the golden stars and ultimately The Queen Fairy!

Name: Ka-Nexus
Description:
Ka-Nexus is a fast-paced, easy to learn card game for two to four players.  It contains a mix of skill, strategy, and chance.  The goal of the game is to score 21 points over the course of two or more hands, each hand taking about 15 minutes to play.

The deck consists of 61 cards, fifteen cards (numbered 1-12, Queen, Pharoah, Camel) each in four suits (Scarabs, Fortune, Markets, Thieves) plus the Royal Camel (a Joker of sorts).  The game board has locations for each player to store cards, an area to build the card pyramids central to game play, a draw pile area (the Oasis) and a discard pile area (the Sphinx).

The game begins by taking 25 cards and using them to build two overlapping pyramids in the center of the game board.  The remaining 36 cards are placed in the Oasis.  Each player's turn consists of drawing a card from the Oasis and then making as many "tricks" as possible, where a "trick" is defined as a combination of two cards that add up to 15 or a lone Camel (similar to the classic Pyramid Solitaire game).  Cards for "tricks" may come from the player's personal storage area (which may hold up to 3 cards), the top of the Sphinx pile, or uncovered cards in the pyramid structure.  A player's turn ends when he takes the drawn card and either makes a trick with it, places it in storage, discards it to the Sphinx, or exchanges it with a card already in storage and discards that card to the Sphinx.

When all of the cards from the Oasis have been drawn and played, the hand ends and players score points for: the Last Royal Trick (last trick played that contains a Queen, Pharaoh, or Camel) for 1 point, Pyramids (clearing the last card from the pyramids) for i point, Majority (most tricks captured) for 2 points, Scarabs (most Scarab suit cards captured) for 2 points, and Camels at 1 point per captured Camel.  Players are penalized for cards remaining in their storage area at the end of a hand.  Maximum score per hand is 11 points.

Name: Nelly Natter
Description: The players move their snake in order to surround face-down markers which will indicate what action will then occur - for example an apple which enables the snake to grow. The snakes are made from wooden sections which link together. They are moved by holding one link in place and moving another section so that the snake wriggles to its destination. A turn ends when another piece is touched. The winner is the player to first get his snake to full size - a head plus 12 body sections.

Name: Åkar-spelet
Description:
Åkar-spelet is a promotional game released by the Swedish branch of Esso, now a brand of ExxonMobile, around the time when the company was sold to Norwegian Statoil in 1985.

Players take on the role of one of four hauliers; the bus, the truck (pictured as a dump truck for some reason), the excavator or the soda van. In each round of the game, players draws a mission from the deck matching his or her role and then take turns to throw dice and move their playing piece around the board to complete the mission and get back to their respective headquarters first.
Along the way they have to avoid red numbered squares, 83 in total, that correspond to a bad event, like a parking ticket, or could make you draw a Chance! card that are divided 50/50 between good and bad. They also have to avoid refueling squares that make you go to the very nearest fuel station and pay for fuel before you may proceed. Players are however encouraged to buy different kinds of Esso solutions that make this cheaper or even make you immune within a radius of your headquarters.

The number of rounds played are variable between one and ten and the goal is to have the most money when the game is over. The first player to complete the mission each round get a bonus, the second a smaller bonus and the third an even smaller bonus but the last player, no matter if second, third or fourth, instead get a late fee for every space left on the mission. Red numbered squares often make you lose a turn or charge you a fee while the five good Chance! cards often give a sizable reward. Missions also often give a cash reward for one or more steps or a larger reward when completed.

Name: Top Spot
Description: Be the first to get three spots in a row and you win! But watch out... Overlapping cards let you cover each other's spots! This tic-tac-toe variant is composed of two-colored cards (red-blue, red-blank, blue-blank, or blank-blank) and allows for some strategy as each player holds two cards and chooses which to play.

Name: Hailstorm
Description:
From Hypothermia #15:

Hailstorm is a quick, easy, luck-based game intended to feel vaguely like craps or roulette.  If Icehouse pieces are the new playing cards, then perhaps this shall be the first of many games that will be played in the casinos of the future, when people who enjoy losing money when they play will be able to do so while playing with pyramids.

It requires drawing pieces out of a bag, and dropping them.  If it end up pointing straight up, you get the piece.  If it land flat, you get any pieces it is pointing at.  THe first person to complete a tree of a single color wins.

Betting rules are included.

Name: Tribes of Pangea
Description:
Pangea is the prehistoric one continent world.  Each time you open Tribes of Pangea, you will create a new one-continent world to explore.  Players seed the world with unknown resources to explore and use them to either build their own infrastructure, or to conquer opponent tribes.

Players win by defeating all opponent tribes in Pangea.  Victory is usually reached with a balanced strategy of war, economy, and fame.

Each turn your tribe is not starving, you get more population, which means you can gather more resources, build more infrastructure, and build more armies with which to gain control of even more resources... until Pangea is yours.

The game typically takes between 3 and 5 hours.  While only having an 11 page rule book, the game does have some considerable learning curve.

The game features include: 
  * a random setup, to ensure a new game every time you play
  * a battle resolution table to facilitate rolling dice for battles
  * 3 types of military units, melee, ranged, and magic
  * buildings and resources that can upgrade military units
  * a system of fame and bribing, if you decide that war isn't going to work for you!

2-6 players, ages 12 and up
Contents: 56 building counters, 36 resource counters, 180 military counters, 5 dice, 6 tribe cards, 1 battle resolution table, 36 continent and ocean hexes, 18 roads, 66 counting chip counters, 11 page rule book, 6 page reference almanac.

Name: Hockinole
Description:
Hockinole combines two all-time favorite Canadian board games, table hockey and crokinole.

This is a variant of Crokinole played on a rectangular rink instead of a circle.  Similar to Crokinole, the goal is to flick your disks into a hole.  The holes in this case are in the 'nets' at the ends of the rink rather than at the center of the board.

Name: Six Gun Assassins
Description:
Grab your Guns, the Wild West is about to get Wilder! Welcome to the World of Six-Gun Assassins, a fast play, rip roaring gunslingin’ good time! Easy to learn and fun to play, Six-Gun Assassins has something for everyone!

Rebel Minis' Place & Play rules make it easy to live out your wild west adventures, grab your favorite figs, git on your horse and start raising a ruckus. Create your own scenarios with these core rules or try your hand that some of the scenarios provided.

Six-Gun Assassins has it all, so Saddle up outlaws there's some gun fighting to be had.

17 pages

Name: The Driving Spirit Safety Game
Description:
Players answer trivia questions, mostly about Alfa Romeo. The person to answer correctly wins the card. Each card has a letter a letter on it (M,I,L,A,N or O). The first person to spell out "MILANO" (home of the game's maker) wins.

Game Contents:
Playing board 
1 die 
4 markers 64 cards- 10 each M,I,L,A,N,O 
4 blanks 
Instructions

Name: Break Down
Description:
The object of this game of words is to:  score more points than your opponents by forming words from a starter word, stopping the round of play, and by predicting whether your opponents found the same words.

Restrictions:  found words must appear in a standard dictionary, without using proper nouns or abbreviations;  Letters may be used in each found word more than once--up to the number of times that letter appears in the starter word; and found words may not be formed by adding an "s" to an existing found word.

Name: Woidz
Description: A guessing game with seventeen rounds, where opponents try to determine the secret word of the opponent by asking questions and wagering guesses.

Name: The War Room: The Persian Gulf Conflict
Description:
Played on a map of the Middle East. 4 factions are
Blue: Saudi Arabia, Oman, Qatar, UAE. 
Green: Egypt, Jordan, Syria, Turkey, Sinai,Israel, Lebanon. 
Red: Iraq, Kuwait, Iran. 
Amber: Sudan, Ethiopia, Somalia Yemen.

All forces are equal in units and types.  Combat is A&A like with different hit numbers based on attacking and defending units.  All factions has a deck of action cards.

Teams are Blue/Green Vs Red/Amber.

Has timed moves

Name: minizoomerz: Wild Canyons Toolkit
Description:
The Wild Canyons Toolkit is an extension to the Print and Play minizoomerz Basic Game. It contains a wide selection of track sections which can be used to design and create your own track layouts and circuits.

The Toolkit introduces separate Finish Lines so that point-to-point races can be created in addition to circuit racing.

Also included are Checkpoint counters so that players can create races with an alternative win condition.

A number of restricted sections add additional variety to the layouts you can build.

The sections include:

- Left and Right starting grids (1-4, 5-8, 9-12)
- 2 Finishing Lines and 8 Checkpoints
- 4 Left and 4 Right tight (90 degree) corners
- 3 Left and 3 Right long (45 degree) curves
- 2 Short, 2 Open (medium) and 2 Long straights
- 1 Split, 1 Chicane, and 2 Restricted sections.
- 1 Left and 1 Right 90 degree corner with center lane blocked
- 2 overpass sections
- 6 Tunnel Entrances/Exits
- 24 assorted rocky obstacles

NOTE: The minizoomerz Basic Game is required to use this product.

Expands:

    minizoomerz Basic Game

Name: HeroCard Galaxy EGG Expansion Deck
Description:
From the back of the box:

EGG Expansion Deck

The EGG attacks with its arsenal of quantum weapons to overload, overwhelm, and overpower the enemy.

The EGG is a HeroCard Galaxy expansion deck, the battle for cosmic domination. The EGG can compete in any HeroCard game or be combined with other decks to create a customized character.

Contents
33 Character cards
1 Figure

Expands

    HeroCard Galaxy

Name: HeroCard Galaxy Crab Expansion Deck
Description:
From the back of the box:

Crab Expansion Deck

The Crab eliminates enemies using her overwhelming neutral voltage, rapid reflexes, and intense energy shields.

The Crab is a HeroCard Galaxy expansion deck , the battle for cosmic domination. The Crab can compete in any HeroCard game or be combined with other decks to create a customized character.

Contents
33 Character cards
1 Figure

Expands

    HeroCard Galaxy

Name: Herd the Sheep
Description:
The shepherds want to lead their sheep back to the warm barn. Who will be the first to lure, with delicious flowers, their sheep back from the meadow? This competitive game for 2-4 players has a tactical variation for experienced players.

Ages 4-12.

From HABA USA

Name: Die kleine Maus
Description:
Rummy Game for 3 of more players.

32 cards.

Object of the game
To collect and lay in front of you as many sets of 4 matching cards as possible.  A quartet is made up of 4 cards with the same symbols or the same numbers.

The cards, illustrated by Helmut Spanner, show pictures of cute little mice playing with objects from around the home.

Name: Mongolian Goat Rodeo
Description:
The object of Mongolian Goat Rodeo is to grab the goat from one corner of the play area, then carry it down to the opposite corner, around a goat post, and back to the starting location. There's only one goat, so players will tussle over who has control. The object of the game is to get the most victory points. Three points are up for grabs in the rodeo and up to ten points are available from bragging rights afterwards.

On a turn, a player rolls 2d6 for each of his three riders to determine how far they can go. A ruler is used to measure the distance moved.  If a rider ends his move adjacent to the goat, he can tussle for it. To do that, the player must explain how he takes possession of the goat. Based on the quality of the story, another player judges the likelihood on a d6 roll of the active player taking possession.  "Unexpected events" are handled similarly. At any point a player may spend a coin from their hand and declare one. They describe what happens and then another player decides its likelihood.

Once the goat it safely back to the starting point, the players may spend any remaining coins, with each coin granting an argument to try to gain more victory points. These may relate to things that happened during the rodeo or to post-rodeo festivities that would make a team look better in the eyes of the spectators. Once all the coins are gone, the winner is determined.

The first edition of Mongolian Goat Rodeo (2006) was a board game, while the second edition (2013) is a card game in which players need to supply their own dice, ruler and coins in order to play. The designer has also published free "miniatures game" rules that can be played using any mounted figures. See the Community Wiki section, below.

Name: Lach dich schlapp!
Description:
A uno variant with words/sentences.
Each player in turn plays a card - either an action card, or a proper text card (numbered 1-5) to start/extend/complete the current sentence. If unable to do so, the player must draw a card. Goal is to be the first player without cards.
The played text cards form silly sentences, for example:  
"The waiter"  "embraces"  "a stinking"  "ghost"  "in the garden".

Name: Race for the Gold!
Description:
Be the first pirate to reach the lost treasure!
 Players roll the dice and move their three colored playing figures along the board, hoping to reach the ships, which will take them to Treasure Island, where the golden treasure lies.  On every turn, players have several options - they can split the roll of the dice and move two players along, they can use one or both of the rolls to move the ships at sea, or they can try to send an opponent home. In Race for the Gold™ the ultimate goal is to reach the golden treasure first! Players use unique finger grooves in the game board to move the ships around the game board. The longer they sail, the more likely they will encounter danger!
A pirate can fall overboard, or a ship can sink, causing all on board to begin the journey again. The player whose pirate reaches the treasure first is the winner!

Name: Pocket Pastimes Motor Racing
Description:
From the box: 
Two to four people may compete, each choosing one peg as a car. The pegs are then lined up at the starting post. Each player in turn throws the dice and moves their peg the number of sections thrown. If a six is thrown, you get another throw. If a player should land on the following numbers; 8, 15, 20, 26, 32, 36, 45, 50, 57, 69, 78, 82, follow the appropriate instructions. The winner is the first player to reach no. 86.

Name: This Very Ground: Skirmish Wargaming in the French & Indian War
Description: This Very Ground is a miniature wargaming system designed to recreate small unit skirmish combat during the French & Indian War. This system is primarily designed for 28mm miniatures, but can be adapted to virtually any miniature scale.

Name: Olympics
Description:
Compete in various Olympic sports.

Several events are played at once.  You move a counter around the outside of the board - the space it lands on allows you to move pieces in certain events or to collect cards that affect your athletes performance.

Name: Birth of A Nation American Civil War Rules
Description:
A set of medium to large scale wargames rules for the American Civil War period 1861 to 1865.

Units are organized into Brigades and commanded at Divisional level for the Confederation and at Corp level for the Union.

A very simple command ordering system allows a fast flowing game to unfold right before your eyes. This is achieved through a command structure where commanders must keep their troops motivated or their formation and army morale may crumble. Control of the battle is achieved through a series of morale checks; these are effortless and give extremely good historical results. You may find your units running for cover when you least desire it, then find that they return with a new resolve and vigor for the fight.

These rules are capable of reproducing all the major battles of the American Civil War from Bull Run 21st July 1861 through to Parnetto Ranche 13th May 1865.

Name: Octi for Kids
Description:
Modified version of original Octi especially for kids.  The object of the game is to move one of your pieces onto one of your opponent's starting squares. On each move players decide whether to upgrade their existing pieces or move a piece. Simple movement and Checkers-like jumping keep players rethinking their possible strategies.  
Recommended for ages 6+
Families: Versions & Editions: Junior Versions of Grown-Up Games

Name: Alice in Wonderland Card Game
Description: The Alice in Wonderland Card Game is a deck of 48 cards featuring John Tenniels illustrations. The pack consists of 16 sets of 3 cards each, all bearing the same number. One card in each set is the Leading card, and shows on its face the titles of the two other cards in the set. For example, the leading card in the first set is "Alice Telescoping" with the instructions "Find the 'Rabbit running away' and The 'Fan.' The objective of the game is to complete the most sets. Players accomplish this by playing a Leading card face up in front of them and then calling on other players for the cards that make up the set, in a manner similar to the classic card game "Go Fish."

Name: Musingo
Description:
A Musical Surprise Game. Musingo by Mattel. Stock #461.
For ages 5 to 10.
Players use one of four different bingo cards and a plastic monkey counter. A racetrack around the perimeter of your bingo card has some squares with coin icons and some with music box icons.  Roll your D6 and if you land on a coin icon, take a coin from the bank.  Land on the music box icon and, if you have a coin, place it in the slot in the music box and turn the crank.  After the Musingo song plays, a slot-machine-like roller will spin and display up to three notes in one of the five colors of the bingo card rows and columns.  Cover a square on your bingo card matching the color(s) displayed on the music box. First person to make a row, column or diagonal wins. 
Contains: 4 Monkey Playing pieces; 4 Individual Musingo Boards; 1 die; 48 Musingo Markers; 50 plastic coins; and the 'Musingo' man, an 8 inch plastic music box shaped and colored as mustachioed organ grinder.

Name: Zombie Cafe
Description:
Zombie Cafe is a game of zombies and brains. You had a nice little delicatessen, but that was before The Change. Overnight, your best customers became zombies, and a zombie's favorite food is brains. Fortunately your meat supplier also turned into a zombie, so getting your standing orders changed from pastrami and corned beef to brains and more brains wasn't difficult.

Zombie Cafe is a game of selling. Players are dealt five Brains from a Brain deck, each brain has a numeric value assigned indicating quality. The first player to sell all of their brains wins! Sounds easy, right?  Of course it isn't! During your turn you play modifiers from the Cafe deck on your brains to improve their quality and make them easier to sell, you play modifiers on other player's brains to decrease their quality and make them harder to sell, and general chaos ensues! It's not uncommon for one player to think they have it made and they'll go out on their next turn when suddenly a flurry of cards are played and they now have four more brains to deal with.

The game is fast to play, is good for 2-6 players (you could try eight players, but you'll exhaust the Brain deck pretty quickly), and a game usually lasts 20-30 minutes. One page of rules (double-sided), 52 Brain cards, and 52 Cafe cards. You will need two six-sided dice per player.

Home Page : http://www.sparebrainsgames.com/zombiecafe.html

Name: Inspector Morse
Description: This board game is based on the TV series, features the first three episodes of Inspector Morse. You must collect clues from different places. Visit the police station to examine the police records of the suspects. Even visit Morse’s office to check out his notebook and the case notes. The game includes 3 cases, each with three 6-question cards which makes total of 9 different mysteries to play. Players gain or lose points from promotional cards and by answering as many of the questions as possible.

Name: Gundam Axis UC0078
Description:
A Strategic Wargame base on the Gundam Universe. Players control factions in the U.C Gundam story line. The map depicts areas of the Earth and various "Sides"(artificial environment for people to live in space).

Plays factions from the original Gundam up to double Zeta Gundam. Units represent Mobile suits, spaceships and factories.

Players also manage production of units and economy.

Components: rules, mapboard, 180 cards, 1056 counters, dice (both D20 and D6), record sheets, reference card, and counter trays.

Very Japanese intensive.

Rated 5 on difficulties of Tsukuda Hobby

product game number: HG-078

Name: An Illusion of Victory: The Battle of Na San
Description: An LPS bonus mini-game, An Illusion of Victory simulates the French win at Na San (Nov. 30 - Dec. 2 1952) which convinced the French they could defeat the Viet Minh and led them eventually to Dien Bien Phu.

Name: Pantin Nocturne
Description:
A miniatures game set in the role-playing universe of Mechanical Dream. Pantin Nocturne uses an ordinary chessboard, or terrain broken into a similar grid, to regulate the movement of its miniatures. Playing pieces are referred to as "puppets" and are divided into "pawns" and champions," with varying abilities. Each player utilizes a "cell" of eight puppets. The game is resolved without the use of of dice.

The rule book and the two Cells required to play are each sold separately.   A playing board ~ chess, checkers, or other similar grid ~ must be supplied to play the game.

Name: Springline
Description:
Adapted from the package text:

Springline: simple to learn, easy to lose. Springline is a wild, fast moving and unpredictable game of skill and tactics for two, in which moves lead to chain reactions, prisoners return to the game and pieces bounce off the edge of the board.

The board is a hexagonal grid with five spaces along each edge, and is positioned between the players with a corner pointing toward each player. The corner spaces are return pads with the three closest pads belonging to their respective players. There are eight pieces for each player that begin on the three closest return pads, midway between them along the near edges, and two spaces forward of each of the central three pieces. Moves are one space in a straight line or in a hexagonal orbit around any other piece. Three (or more) pieces in a line form a Springline, and either end(s) must discharge before the end of a turn. Discharged pieces travel in a series of straight unobstructed lines (bouncing off the edges of the board as necessary) as far as the player wants. Capture is by replacement, and prisoners are immediately exchanged upon capture. Exchanged prisoners must be re-entered onto one of a player's own vacant return pads at the earliest opportunity. Failure to be able to do so (because they are occupied) loses the game. Alternatively, if a player holds, even for a moment, three opposing prisoners, this wins the game.

Name: Golf-Dice Challenge!
Description:
A standard Golf simulation driven by 5 different dice replacing golf clubs.

Game components:

- 6 dice 
- score pad 
- a cute little case for the dice presenting as a golf bag 
- a pencil

Name: Colmo
Description:
The board is the outer 5 concentric rings of a 14x14 square grid, with the middle 4x4 area out of play. The rings are partially separated by walls. Each player has 10 pieces, 2 each that can move 2, 3, 4, 5 and 6 spaces.

Players compete to be the first to score 11 points by completing widdershin circuits of the board and/or capturing opposing pieces. Pieces may turn corners and pass through gaps in the walls between rings to take shorter paths, and may pass over linear groups of connected pieces (considering the whole group as one space in the movement), but may not move backwards more than a quarter of the distance around the board from their starting points and may not occupy the same space more than once during the same move. Opposing pieces that are not part of a linked group may be captured by displacement.

United Kingdom of Great Britain Patent GB9520980.5, applied 13 October 1995, granted 7 July 1999.

Name: Frères d'Armes
Description:
Frères d'Armes is a rule of game for every period of history, romans, medieval and even Fantasy.
It's a skirmish game with collectible figures, and you can also use it for role playing.
You need about ten figurines of any sort in each team, one die (10,20 or 30)and a few coins.
28 mm figurine are all right for this game.
You can find resin figurines for this game sold by the publisher.
Notice that the rules are in French and in english.
Expansion are all in french.

Name: Cobras in the Cockpit
Description:
From the website:

Cobras in the Cockpit is a game based on a fictional movie where YOU play the SNAKES! Your objective: throw the plane into chaos! You will hiss, rattle, squeeze, and bite your way through the plane, earning points for each section you throw into chaos. But other snakes will try to stop you, so watch out!

There are 4 types of snakes: Cobras, Rattlesnakes, Kingsnakes, and Pythons, each one having special abilities that make them unique. Each player chooses a breed of snake to play and then moves their snakes through the plane, trying to scare the passengers and crew. When all sections of the plane have been thrown into chaos, the game is over and the snakes with the most points win.

Beware of the Bad Mother F$%#@! and the Air Marshall! Spook people with snakes on a plate and snakes in the head! But don't forget that snakes don't plan good and snakes can barely see!*

The game comes with a 5 piece board, a deck of 99 cards, 4 snake species cards, 20 snake markers, 10 chaos markers, rulebook, and scoresheet.

Cobras in the Cockpit supports 2-4 players and the average game takes 30-60 minutes.


     actual names of cards; bad grammar intended

Name: You're It!
Description:
This is a simple party game.

From the website:

There are 7 wood cubes with numbers from 1-7 in 4 different languages (French, German, English and Spanish). Each cube has a different gradient of red.

The player who is "IT" must start turning over the cards one-by-one. When a NOT-IT card is turned over, nothing happens.

When a YOU'RE IT card is turned over, it will have one of 4 commands: LOWEST IS IT, HIGHEST IS IT, REDDEST IS IT or WHITEST IS IT. At this point players race to reach the cube that is the opposite of the card.

Example: LOWEST IS IT, players will try to grab the highest number cube so they are not it. But wait, some of the cards say LOWEST IS NOT IT in this case players would try to grab the cube with the lowest number.

The player that ends up "IT" will start flipping the cards.

When a YOU'RE OUT card is turned over, the player who is "IT", is eliminated and the rest of the players race to see who will be "IT" next.

Be the last player standing and receive a "Winner Chip". Be the player with the most "Winner Chips" after 10 rounds and win the game.

Great for reflexes! Great for parties, Great for family fun.

Name: Vallco Professional Drag Racing Game
Description: Vallco Professional Drag Racing game simulates actual NHRA Drag Racing performances in Top Fuel, Funny Car and Pro Stock categories from 1975 through 1980 seasons. Game includes colorful box, individual driver cards with photo of car, game board drag strip, elapsed time and speed charts, instructions, dice, broke deck. Deluxe Masters Edition includes 96 driver cards, nameless cards, match race only cards, instruction sheets, plastic cars.  Vallco also published a Pro Comp driver set for two years. Cards were available for four seasons. Came to be known as "The Strat-O-matic of auto racing games. Some are still available from creator, contact greg@gregzyla.com for information for info on ziplock plastic bag games with complete, original cards, instructions, etc. Game board and box cover are simulated, but work well.

Name: Glak
Description: Glak is a light abstract strategy area enclosure game played on a modular board with the same components as its sibling Glik. Players try to enclose as much territory as possible using their stones and walls present on the board by adding new stones and moving the ones already on the board.

Name: Rogue Football League
Description:
UPDATED TO VERSION 2 - updated graphics and more streamlined gameplay!

Rogue Football League is a quasi-simulation of the construction and operation of a professional football league in the 1970’s and early 1980’s.  In RFL, players take on the role of a franchise manager and coach.  The players will draft rookies, sign free agents, manage franchise finances and try to make a run at the league championship, all at the same time!  Rogue Football League runs over the course of three seasons, so owners will have plenty of time to see their league grow and succeed.

What makes RFL fun to play is that while players are trying to beat each other on the field, they must work together for the success of the league off the field, or no one wins.

It is not necessary to have eight players to play RFL.  While the game has mechanics for non-player franchises, and can even be played solitaire, interaction is a BIG part of the game.

League models, or templates, are available for leagues of between six and twelve teams. Each individual game on the schedule can be resolved in 3-5 minutes with the two owners rolling against each other, or a quick play function is available if owners wish to concentrate on the managerial/financial aspects of the league.

Rogue Football League comes with a 14-page rulebook, 24 franchise cards, 52 veteran cards, 44 rookie cards, 60 event cards, originals of all necessary game forms, and three double-sided player aid cards.

     Two expansions have been released: Foreign Fields, which adds in more league templates, more cards and rules for Canadian/European franchises; and Ghosts of the Past, which adds in more cards, a random event table and scenarios for recreating the USFL, WFL, and WLAF
 Available from Brothers-in-Arms Games at biagamesonline.tripod.com - check out the site and check out the game.

Name: Big Bully
Description: Players move matadors around a board displaying a cartoon bullring trying to hide behind barriers to avoid "Big Bully" - a mechanical wind-up bull which contains a mechanism randomizing the direction of movement.  The last player standing is the winner.

Name: The Name Game: The Celebrity Guessing Game
Description: What's in a name? Each of the cards in this box bears a celebrity's name (from actors to authors, sports figures to politicians, musicians to TV personalities), and the object of the game is to get your teammates to guess as many names as they can in a series of 1-minute rounds. Give clues to describe the celebrity on the card, do it quickly, and don't say the celebrity's name! It's wildly addictive and suitable for teens on up.

Name: Stars Divided: Terran Civil War
Description:
The Stars are Divided

Mankind reached the stars, and for hundreds of years has lived confident and supreme in the galaxy. Only one alien race was discovered, and that lone example of intelligence was conquered and enslaved. It was that victory, those acts, which sowed the seeds of mankind's greatest threat. On the verge of discovering that man was not supreme in the galaxy, humanity turned upon itself.

It was an age of idealism. It was an age of elitism. It was an age when man turned against man, confident in his own superiority. It was an age of ignorance... when man strode too proudly amongst the stars.

Included in this book is everything you need to play out the story of the Terran Civil War with the VBAM and Starmada X game systems, including: 
 * Rules to model internal politics for VBAM
 * Expanded links between VBAM-Starmada abilities
 * Rules for designing new Starmada weapon systems
 * Expanded fighter design rules
 * New ground force design rules
 * New scouting options
 * New planetary facilities
 * Enhanced Starmada-VBAM scenario/setup rules
 * Expanded elite officer and crew rules
 * 27 Starmada ship designs
 * Complete orders of battle for "historical" play
 * In depth campaign setting and background
 * "Historical" scenarios for Starmada play
 * 50+ star systems, based loosely on real stellar cartography

THIS IS NOT A STAND ALONE PRODUCT AND REQUIRES THE Victory by Any Means: Campaign Guide(VBM-101) AND Victory by Any Means: The Starmada Edition (MJG-0113) TO FULLY USE. OWNERSHIP OF THE Victory by Any Means: Campaign Moderator's Companion (VBM-105) IS RECOMMENDED.

Expanded by:

    Victory by Any Means: Campaign Guide and Victory by Any Means: The Starmada Edition (both are required)
    Victory by Any Means: Campaign Moderator's Companion

Name: The Sex Game
Description:
We would have called it the "Love Making Game" but let's face it, The Sex Game just sounds better.  Don't be fooled though, The Sex Game is all about making love and exchanging ideas.  Created for you and your lover as a means to encourage playfulness, stimulate secret sexual delights, while also bringing new and exciting elements into your love life...

Okay, okay... it's really about getting LUCKY! But get too cocky!  The Sex Game is a bit of a gamble.  After all, you could end up rolling "Solo in the Garage"  Think you can handle the odds?  Take a chance and see what you can roll up between you and your partner!

Name: Iroquoia: The Beaver Wars
Description:
From the rules: "In the early 1600s the Iroquois Five Nations initiated a number of wars to gain control of the beaver trade.  Each of 3 to 5 players represents a clan (Wolf, Bear, Turtle, Eagle, or Deer) within the Iroquois Confederation during this time and attempts to gain control of Confederation policy and the beaver trade."

There are two main elements that players must deal with - influencing the five nations to follow your clan and attacking the enemy tribes.

Each nation grants a different benefit when it follows your leadership. Control of a nation is determined with an area control/influence mechanism.  If one is willing to surrender their influence during a council turn, more beaver tokens (victory points) are earned.

When attacking neighboring tribes, other clans may join yours in the attack.  Their help will improve the chances of victory, but means the spoils will be shared.  Success is determined by a simple superiority of numbers after the defending tribe has had a chance to eliminate the attackers.  Success earns the survivors a share of that tribe's beaver furs.

Name: Fuzzy Sooper Heroes
Description:
The first expansion to the great, and funny, Fuzzy Heroes miniature rules for stuffed animals and action figures, Fuzzy Sooper Heroes adds special powers and special rules to the Fuzzy Heroes Game.
The new rules increase the role playing content of the game, however it remains at the core a miniatures wargame.

Name: Heroes in Space
Description: The third expansion to the Fuzzy Heroes universe in fact takes the game off Terra Firma and into the universe beyond. After a medieval/fantasy theme, a supper hero and a secret agent game, Inner City now tackles SciFi for fuzzy heroes and plastic foes. Rules for ship-to-ship combat using plastic models and vehicles are added, these are independent of the existing Fuzzy Heroes rules.

Name: Under the Covers
Description:
In the second expansion to the Fuzzy Heroes miniature game, covert rules are added that insert elements of espionage, gadgets and general secrecy.
As with all Fuzzy Heroes games, there is a distinct role playing component to this wargame, though in this game it is perhaps more obvious than the previous ones.

Expands:

    Fuzzy Heroes

Name: The Lost Toys
Description:
This time, the Fuzzy Heroes venture into the world of horror. Undead toys stalk the floor of your bedroom.
More than any previous book, this Fuzzy Heroes product depends strongly on storytelling and roleplaying elements.
Introducing rules for undeath(a toy-virus), slaying (Spraying...) and related special powers.
Fluffy must use all her "Spraying" abilities to make the world safe for stuffed animals once more.
Hilarious as always.

Expands

    Fuzzy Heroes

Name: Plastic Ships and Fuzzy Men
Description:
The sixth installment in the Fuzzy Heroes line sends you favorite stuffed animals out to see. It introduces rules for ship building, ship-to-ship combat and even pirate-talk for beginners.
The rules are separate from the main Fuzzy Heroes rule set, but they greatly complement each other.
Another fine installment in this humorous line will make you want to dig out your childhood favorites and head to the nearest toy store to pick up that big pirate ship you never had.

Expands:

    Fuzzy Heroes

Name: Formula 1 Grand Prix
Description: Racing game, where players race against each other for gathering points. Player with most points after four circuits is the winner.A simpel roll and move game. A kids game!

Name: Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone Quidditch Chapter Game
Description:
This is a game in the Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone Chapter Game series, in which games are contained in a portable box designed to look like a book, and the theme of the game corresponds to chapters in the film, Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone.

From the back of the blister packaging:

Use the book game board to carry your game pieces.

Play Seekers Harry Potter and Terence Higgs as they compete for the elusive Golden Snitch.

Score points with the Quaffle and ultimately "catch" the Golden Snitch.

Roll the die and try to hit your opponents with the Bludger, knocking them off their broom.

Contents: 1 mini game book, 1 Quidditch grid, 4 support arms, 2 movers (Harry, Terence), 1 Golden Snitch, 1 Quaffle, 1 Bludger, 2 dice (number, letter), 6 customer applied labels

Name: Miss Spider's Tea Party Card Game
Description:
Each player starts with 7 cards in their hands and is trying to get all of Miss Spider's friends in a set in front of them.  To do this, they ask a person for the card they need, and either take the card from that person, or gets a card from the draw or discard piles.  The first person to get all the friends (no duplicates) is the winner.

A simple card game, listed on the box as for ages 4 and up.

Name: Sky High
Description:
In this dexterity game, players build a tower out of variously shaped wooden blocks based upon dice rolls. The results of a roll table indicate whether you must try to use all the blocks left in the kitty, or only one block. Often, the result of the roll indicates the shape of a block that you must place on top of the tower. Completing the tower grants you 15 points, causing the tower to collapse on your turn grants all the other players points equal to the number of blocks left in the kitty. There is an exception: if you fail in your attempt to place the very last block atop the tower, each other player gets 15 points. The game is played to a 50 point total.

The year, 1972, is a guess, as the game is unmarked.  However the box is very similar to "Penta-Logics," which did come out in 1972, hence the guess.

Name: Makili
Description:
A memory game. It's not easy to remember an unlikely story card after card: In the snow, a King on a motorcycle saw a spider...

Contains 90 Cards, for ages 5 and up.

Name: Fleets
Description:
Players start out with a few ships in one of 9 "quadrants". On each turn, you gain ships based on the number of star bases you've conquered plus a bonus ship for each quadrant you completely control. Only one ship is allowed per space and each ship can move up to 3 spaces in any direction. You can then attack single enemy ships with 1 to 3 ships of your own at a time. The defender rolls one die and the attacker rolls as many dice as ships used in the attack. Whoever rolls the single highest die removes one enemy ship involved in the fight. Ties result in no losses. The game continues until one player controls a set number of quadrants, i.e. 3 quadrants in a 4-player game.
The designer released a the very-similar Stargate SG-1, based on the sci-fi TV show. That version adds ground troops and action cards but uses the same board.

Re-implemented by:

    Stargate SG-1

Name: Line of Battle (Second Edition)
Description:
Line of Battle - Tactical simulation between capital ships. The game covers the period 1914-1924

Line of Battle recreates naval battles during the era of the Dreadnought battleship. A unique combat system simulates shell strengths, immune zones, armor placement, gun ranges and the angle of incoming shot without resorting to complex calculations. Take command of a squadron of dreadnoughts to duel for domination of the seas.

This is the updated by Omega Games (i.e. Second Edition). It features all new artwork, revised and re-edited rules and several playing aids not found in the originals.

Re-implements:

    Line of Battle: Tactical Capital Ship Combat, 1914-1924
Families: Series: Dreadnought combat games (SimCan / Omega Games)

Name: Whipped!
Description:
From the box copy:

In the game of Whipped!, you're a regular guy trying to hold onto your friends and the lady in your life. Your garage band may breakup when she throws out your guitar, or you may never hear from good old Chuck again after he sees you carrying her purse at the mall! Boost your male pride with an Iron John weekend, or flagellate yourself silly at the Relationship Counselor. Hilarious surprises and upsets abound in this light-hearted parody. If you haven't yet, it's time to get Whipped!

Game description:
Each player starts with three "friend" cards in play. The goal of the game is to be the last person with a friend in play. On a player's turn they draw their hand up to 7 cards and then play a card. Blue "Bond" cards are played on friends to "strengthen" the friendship. Pink "Whipped" cards are played to remove bond or friend cards from other players. Yellow special cards give you special actions (play all bonds in your hand, etc) and green special cards allow you to avoid or cancel a card played by another player.

Name: Connect Four Cube
Description:
This is Connect4 played on a cube.

The "cube" is about 3 inches on a side and cannot be accurately called a cube since the edges and corners are cut off at 45 degrees. It is made of the same blue plastic as the more common Connect4 game. Each of the 26 sides thus created has a hole in.

The cube is hollow and one side is a door enabling red and yellow pegs to be stored inside the cube. This, and the wrist strap secured to the inside of the cube (stored inside during play), make the game very portable.

The gameplay is similar to Connect4 - place a peg in a hole on your turn. The object is to get four in a row.

Name: Task Forces at War
Description: Task Forces at War is a really quick card game for two, pitting the Axis' and Allies' naval vessels against one another.  Players secretly and simultaneously select three ships from their hand of five, then reveal the chosen three.  Each ship has three combat values, namely aircraft, big guns, and torpedoes.  If there are four or more aircraft carriers, then the battle will be a carrier battle, and all ships use their aircraft.  If, instead, there are five or more battleships, all ships will use their big guns.  Otherwise, the ships will employ their torpedoes.  Once the type of battle is identified, the players total their combat strengths, then compare them.  The player with the higher total sinks one of the opponent's ships.  Generally, the loser selects the ship to sacrifice; however, if the winner has double or more the combat value of the loser, then the winner sinks whichever ship she likes.  Once the decks are exhausted, the round is complete, and the player who has sunk the higher total victory point value of ships wins the round.  Winning two rounds wins the game.

Name: Numberland Counting Game
Description:
An introduction to numbers:

The object of the game is to collect the largest number of diecut pictures.

Each player selects a different pawn, and places it on start.  The youngest player goes first.

The first player takes to top card from the DECK and moves along the path to the next square that matches the color drawn, or if a picture card is drawn, directly to the numeral space on the path matching the numeral in the upper left corner of the card.

The game ends when one player reaches the red HOME space, or when all the plastic numerals have been removed from the playing board.  Home is reached by drawing a single or double red color card when there are no other red spaces on the path in front of the player, or by drawing a card that would take him beyond HOME if the path continued.  He fills out the home card, like a numeral card.

Name: Sesame Street Fair
Description:
Description from rules:

Come on over to Sesame Street and be there for a STREET FAIR.  Grover is serving cookies from his stand, and the merry-go-round is beckoning.  You might even get your picture taken by Maria.

The winner is the first player to arrive at 123 Sesame Street with a cookie.  For a longer game, get 3 cookies.  Go back to start and go around twice more.

Name: Berzerkerbirdz
Description: Alien Invazorz have come to the Birdznest Nebula to contest in the Astrobirdz Extreme Sports Arena. The winner of each contest wins a settled world, and only you can decide the fate of your home world and stop the alien invaders from taking over your planet!

Name: Oilfield's Car Quiz
Description: Oilfield’s Car Quiz is the all-new automotive trivia game which explores the history of the automobile from the development of the Model-T to the American muscle car! Here opponents compete as they test their classic car knowledge while playing Oilfield’s unique 30-mile racing board game, or by playing against the competitive and challenging score card system!

Name: Cube Squared
Description:
From the back of the box:
"Taking Strategy to the Next Power"

Cube Squared is an exciting two player strategy game. The object of the game is to be the first player to get a complete set of cubes and cylinders, in each of the six colors, off the board and onto their twelve "Home Spots".

This is a classic 2-Player, Abstract Strategy Game where each player is trying to be the first to get a complete set of rainbow colored cubes and cylinders past the square marked with a "star" and off onto their side of the board.

Each game is new and exciting because every game starts with an empty board and players take turns placing one piece at a time anywhere they want on the board except for the two "Home Squares" that have a "star" on them near each end of the board. It doesn't matter if they place a cube or a cylinder or even which color it is because no one player "owns" any piece until it is safely off of the board and onto one of their "home spots" on their side of the board.

Movement rules are pretty short and simple with the key fact being that if there are two pieces of a particular color and shape on the board, those pieces can move either once or twice and once they are
down to one piece, they can only move once. The other main rule is that you MUST get your cube of a color off the board before you get the matching cylinder off the board.

The ability to jump other pieces and move either type of piece, the fact that no one "owns" pieces until they remove them from the board makes for a depth of strategy seen in very few games.

When you add the fact that there is no set starting position for the playing pieces, you will soon see that this game is almost "Bottomless" which gives it the ability to be studied and played for years, if not decades before anyone will ever figure out if there is an optimal setup

Name: Political Favours
Description:
From the rulebook:

Political Favours is a board game for social interaction. In order for a backbencher (ordinary member) to rise up the greasy pole, using favors, deal-making, pay-backs and pork-barreling to both advance and secure their position.

Political Favours is based on skill, chance, strategy, tactics, duplicity, greed and ambition - all the elements necessary to climb up the greasy pole.

The object of the game, and the winner, is the player who can accumulate the greatest number of Favour Tokens. If at the end of the game (or allocated time) there are two or more players with the same number of Tokens, then the amount of cash each player has determines the result.

Name: Charlie and the Chocolate Factory
Description:
This game was designed by Sid Sackson for Alfred A. Knopf.

The basic game is in principle a roll and move with players trying to get through the factory. The dice have been replaced with numbered cards. There are numerous special spaces on the board along the way to represent events in the book.

The illustrations are whimsical and very brightly colored.

Name: Stymie Card Game
Description:
Stymie Card Came. Inspired by the Bewitched T.V. Series. Milton Bradley #4534.
Game parts include 42 playing cards (27 number cards: 0,1,5,& 10 and 15 picture cards 5 each Samantha (+), Endora (-) and Darrin (X)).  There is also a heavy paper mat with areas marked out for the placing of the card sets.
The object of the game is to complete two combinations of two number cards and one picture card to score points.  First player to score 100 wins.

Name: Bearly There
Description:
A set of five six-sided dice in a tube with a leaflet containing rules for Bearly There and two other games (Accumulation and Horse)
The dice are identical, each having have a bear and the  numbers from two to six.

The object of Bearly There is to roll the dice, totaling the numbers and pushing your luck to reach a specific total.
Although it looks like a cuddly teddy, the bear is, in fact, wild. The twist is that you have the option to either add or subtract the wild values from your accumulated total.

The other two games are equally simple, if not more so.

Name: Mekatac
Description: Mekatac: Quick & Dirty Tactical Giant Robot Combat Rules. Design your own Meks or pick from the Lists. Lots of Weapon Types. Can be played Hex/counters or Miniatures. Rules for Transformers, Critical Hits & Pilot Skills. Upgrades & Strategy Card Lists Available. Contributors have added Spaceship Variants, Fan Sites, and Advanced Rules. Easy to balance sides in Scenario creation. Good rule system for large Battles. Pull some dice & figs out, read the rules, and start playing in 10 minutes. Web site: http://www.angelfire.com/games2/warpspawn/MekaT.html

Name: Flip-ball
Description:
A children's dexterity game slightly reminiscent of skee-ball, only you use a small metal catapult to launch the ball instead of one's own hand. A cardboard insert remains in the box to collect low-scoring tosses (ones which don't go through the clown's holes). Another piece of cardboard folds over and stands upright, creating a vertical target.

Points are scored depending on the point value of the hole the ball goes through. First shooter to reach 1000 points is the winner. Original price $1.00. Stands out due to colorful, wacky 60s artwork and type usage, and for the clown actually being not-creepy.

Name: Peanut Butter & Jelly
Description:
Roll the die and collect various parts of a peanut butter and jelly sandwich.

This is apparently a different game than Peanut Butter & Jelly, which also had an edition from Parker Brothers in 1993.

Name: MoneyPower
Description:
Roll the dice and move around the board. Land in certain areas to buy and/or sell investments. Other areas also allow trading and selling of investments to other players. Also, you can purchase investment chips.

Although this is an investment strategy game, the person with the most money is not the winner. The first person to have ten chips is the winner.

Name: Karambolage
Description:
This game with a billiards theme is not a dexterity game as you could expect, but it’s an interesting tactical dice game. Object of the game is to reach as many points as possible by moving the 3 billiard balls across the board with the use of 4 6-sided dice.

Moving the balls is quite unusual, since you don’t move the numbers of the dice rolls, but you must land on fields which show the numbers of these rolls! For that reason, each field of the 7 x 11 gameboard shows a number between 0-6, where the zeros are regarded as jokers. There are several bonus points to achieve - most of them when you manage to hit one ball after the other (like in real billiards). To give you enough strategical possibilities, you are free to choose the billiard ball with which you want to start the moves.

Though the number of players is given from 2-6, it works perfectly as solitaire game, where you can think about your next turn as long as you want.
